H√∂lder's inequality in case of finite non-zero integrals

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : MeasurableSpace Œ±] {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±} {p q : ‚Ñù},
  Real.IsConjugateExponent p q ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {f g : Œ± ‚Üí ENNReal},
      AEMeasurable f ‚Üí
        ‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), f a ^ p ‚àÇŒº ‚â† ‚ä§ ‚Üí
          ‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), g a ^ q ‚àÇŒº ‚â† ‚ä§ ‚Üí
            ‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), f a ^ p ‚àÇŒº ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
              ‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), g a ^ q ‚àÇŒº ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
                ‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), (f * g) a ‚àÇŒº ‚â§ (‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), f a ^ p ‚àÇŒº) ^ (1 / p) * (‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), g a ^ q ‚àÇŒº) ^ (1 / q)
name: ENNReal.lintegral_mul_le_Lp_mul_Lq_of_ne_zero_of_ne_top
docString: H√∂lder's inequality in case of finite non-zero integrals

In an integral domain, the sum of images of distinct elements under a homomorphism maps a finite group to zero unless the homomorphism is the identity function, in which case the sum equals the group's cardinality.

type:
‚àÄ {R : Type u_1} {G : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : Group G] [inst_3 : Fintype G]
  (f : G ‚Üí* R) [inst_4 : Decidable (f = 1)], (Finset.univ.sum fun g => f g) = ‚Üë(if f = 1 then Fintype.card G else 0)
name: sum_hom_units
docString: In an integral domain, the sum of images of distinct elements under a homomorphism maps a finite group to zero unless the homomorphism is the identity function, in which case the sum equals the group's cardinality.

This is the statement of H√∂lder's inequality for integrable functions. It states that, given a measurable space and a measure on this space, and a normed field acting on a normed additively commutative group, if we have an integrable function from the measurable space to the normed group, then for any function from the measurable space to the normed field that is strongly measurable almost everywhere, and whose essential supremum of its norm is finite, the function obtained by pointwise multiplication of these two functions is also integrable. In simpler terms, the scalar multiplication of an integrable vector-valued function by a scalar function with finite essential supremum is integrable.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} {m : MeasurableSpace Œ±} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup Œ≤]
  {ùïú : Type u_5} [inst_1 : NormedField ùïú] [inst_2 : NormedSpace ùïú Œ≤] {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f Œº ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {g : Œ± ‚Üí ùïú},
      MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable g Œº ‚Üí
        essSup (fun x => ‚Üë‚Äñg x‚Äñ‚Çä) Œº ‚â† ‚ä§ ‚Üí MeasureTheory.Integrable (fun x => g x ‚Ä¢ f x) Œº
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.essSup_smul
docString: This is the statement of H√∂lder's inequality for integrable functions. It states that, given a measurable space and a measure on this space, and a normed field acting on a normed additively commutative group, if we have an integrable function from the measurable space to the normed group, then for any function from the measurable space to the normed field that is strongly measurable almost everywhere, and whose essential supremum of its norm is finite, the function obtained by pointwise multiplication of these two functions is also integrable. In simpler terms, the scalar multiplication of an integrable vector-valued function by a scalar function with finite essential supremum is integrable.

If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X ‚Üí E} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure X} {k : Set X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f ‚Üí IsCompact k ‚Üí MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f k
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_isCompact
docString: If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

In an integral domain, the sum of the images of a non-identity group homomorphism from a finite group is zero.

type:
‚àÄ {R : Type u_1} {G : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : Group G] [inst_3 : Fintype G]
  (f : G ‚Üí* R), f ‚â† 1 ‚Üí (Finset.univ.sum fun g => f g) = 0
name: sum_hom_units_eq_zero
docString: In an integral domain, the sum of the images of a non-identity group homomorphism from a finite group is zero.

The theorem states that, for any types Œπ, E, F, given that E and F are both normed additive commutative groups and real vector spaces, and F is a complete space, along with a box 'I' of type 'BoxIntegral.Box Œπ' with Œπ being finite, integration parameters 'l', a function 'f' from Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù to E, and a volume 'vol' of type 'BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Œπ (E ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] F) ‚ä§', a function is integrable with respect to these parameters and volume if and only if for all positive real numbers Œµ, there exists a function 'r' from non-negative real numbers (NNReal) to real numbers such that the function 'r' satisfies the R-condition for all 'c' in NNReal, and for any two non-negative real numbers 'c‚ÇÅ' and 'c‚ÇÇ' and any two tagged pre-partitions 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' of the box 'I', if both 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' are partitions of 'I' that satisfy the base set condition with respect to 'c‚ÇÅ', 'r c‚ÇÅ', 'c‚ÇÇ', and 'r c‚ÇÇ' respectively, then the distance between the integral sums of 'f' with respect to 'vol' over 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' is less than or equal to Œµ. In other words, the integral sums of the function form a Cauchy net, which is a generalization of the Cauchy sequence concept for sets with a more general structure than the real numbers.

type:
‚àÄ {Œπ : Type u} {E : Type v} {F : Type w} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E]
  [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_3 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù F] {I : BoxIntegral.Box Œπ} [inst_4 : Fintype Œπ]
  {l : BoxIntegral.IntegrationParams} {f : (Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù) ‚Üí E} {vol : BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Œπ (E ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] F) ‚ä§}
  [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F],
  BoxIntegral.Integrable I l f vol ‚Üî
    ‚àÄ Œµ > 0,
      ‚àÉ r,
        (‚àÄ (c : NNReal), l.RCond (r c)) ‚àß
          ‚àÄ (c‚ÇÅ c‚ÇÇ : NNReal) (œÄ‚ÇÅ œÄ‚ÇÇ : BoxIntegral.TaggedPrepartition I),
            l.MemBaseSet I c‚ÇÅ (r c‚ÇÅ) œÄ‚ÇÅ ‚Üí
              œÄ‚ÇÅ.IsPartition ‚Üí
                l.MemBaseSet I c‚ÇÇ (r c‚ÇÇ) œÄ‚ÇÇ ‚Üí
                  œÄ‚ÇÇ.IsPartition ‚Üí dist (BoxIntegral.integralSum f vol œÄ‚ÇÅ) (BoxIntegral.integralSum f vol œÄ‚ÇÇ) ‚â§ Œµ
name: BoxIntegral.integrable_iff_cauchy_basis
docString: The theorem states that, for any types Œπ, E, F, given that E and F are both normed additive commutative groups and real vector spaces, and F is a complete space, along with a box 'I' of type 'BoxIntegral.Box Œπ' with Œπ being finite, integration parameters 'l', a function 'f' from Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù to E, and a volume 'vol' of type 'BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Œπ (E ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] F) ‚ä§', a function is integrable with respect to these parameters and volume if and only if for all positive real numbers Œµ, there exists a function 'r' from non-negative real numbers (NNReal) to real numbers such that the function 'r' satisfies the R-condition for all 'c' in NNReal, and for any two non-negative real numbers 'c‚ÇÅ' and 'c‚ÇÇ' and any two tagged pre-partitions 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' of the box 'I', if both 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' are partitions of 'I' that satisfy the base set condition with respect to 'c‚ÇÅ', 'r c‚ÇÅ', 'c‚ÇÇ', and 'r c‚ÇÇ' respectively, then the distance between the integral sums of 'f' with respect to 'vol' over 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' is less than or equal to Œµ. In other words, the integral sums of the function form a Cauchy net, which is a generalization of the Cauchy sequence concept for sets with a more general structure than the real numbers.

        ‚à´ (x : Œ±), ‚à´ (y : Œ≤), f (x, y) ‚àÇŒΩ ‚àÇŒº + ‚à´ (x : Œ±), ‚à´ (y : Œ≤), g (x, y) ‚àÇŒΩ ‚àÇŒº
name: MeasureTheory.integral_integral_add
docString: Double integrals commute with addition.

H√∂lder's inequality for integrable functions: the scalar multiplication of an integrable
scalar-valued function by a vector-value function with finite essential supremum is integrable.
